fields.title: Let’s get you set up
fields.description:
Connecting with people with more divergent perspectives results in creative opportunities, new ways of experimenting and more novel solutions. Therefore, we have developed the Stakeholder Mapping tool: to support you in seeking out and building relationships with unusual suspects to experiment with. 

Let’s start by getting to know the organisation you are mapping.


You can also click here to learn more about why we developed this tool.

fields.title: Congratulations
fields.description:
You successfully created %(organization_name)s's stakeholder map! 

It’s looking rather empty here though, are you ready to add some key stakeholders?

fields.title: Add stakeholders (batch 1 of 4)
fields.description:
Let's start by adding some usual suspects. Try to name at least three of %(organization_name)s's key stakeholders per question. 

Separate stakeholders with COMMAS and press TAB to move to the next question.

Why are we asking this?

In stressful situations, it can be challenging to develop and conduct meaningful experiments. Our recommendation? Collaborate with others in your experiments. There are many benefits: you can support and challenge each other, experience other perspectives, and strengthen your connections. Together, this means the outcomes are more likely to be being meaningful. 

You can also click here to learn more about why we ask you to start by mapping your immediate professional network.

fields.title: Add stakeholders (batch 1 of 4)
fields.description:
Awesome, look at all the stakeholders floating around %(organization_name)s!

I’m sure they are not all equal in terms of closeness, though. Are you ready to indicate how frequently they interact and collaborate with %(organization_name)s?

fields.title: Frequency and depth of contact
fields.description:
Indicate for each stakeholder how frequently they interact with %(organization_name)s, and how many creative collaborations they have had with %(organization_name)s.

The top stakeholder is automatically selected, so you can just tap the correct location in the axis diagram.

fields.title: Interaction diagram
fields.description:
That’s better, isn’t it? 

In this interaction diagram you see an overview of %(organization_name)s's stakeholders and how close they are to %(organization_name)s. The position on the spheres indicates the frequency of interacting (closer to %(organization_name)s is more frequent), and the line types indicate how many creative collaborations have taken place (uninterrupted is many times).


Ready to add some more?

For food and beverage SMEs, we’ve found 6 groups of development influencers and collaborators. Move on to the next page to see which ones, and add some of your own.

fields.title: Add stakeholders (batch 2 of 4)
fields.description:
For food and beverage SMEs, we’ve found six groups of development influencers and collaborators (read more about this here). 

  1. other SMEs in the region or product niche, 
  2. customers and consumer communities, 
  3. the wider food and beverage ecosystem (e.g. chefs, cafes), 
  4. the supply and distribution chain (e.g. farmers, importers, retail chains)
  5. other organizations (eg public funders, universities, associations, companies in other industries such as eg cosmetics or clothing), and 
  6. personal networks (friends, family, hobbies)

fields.title: Frequency and depth of contact
fields.description: Once again, indicate for each stakeholder how frequently they interact with %(organization_name)s, and how many creative collaborations they have had with %(organization_name)s, by tapping the correct location in the axis diagram.

fields.title: Interaction diagram
fields.description:
Well done!

If you want to make a change, you can edit stakeholders by clicking on them.

There are more stakeholders to add though, are you ready to expand %(organization_name)s's network?

fields.title: Add stakeholders (batch 3 of 4)
fields.description: Let's take it a step further down the chain. Again, try to name at least three key stakeholders per question. Separate stakeholders with commas, press tab to move to the next question.

fields.title: Frequency and depth of contact
fields.description: Same as the last time, indicate for each stakeholder how frequently they interact with %(organization_name)s, and how many creative collaborations they have had with %(organization_name)s.

fields.title: Interaction diagram
fields.description:
Awesome, we are getting very close to a complete stakeholder map. 

There is just one more batch of stakeholders to add, are you ready to find some parallels?

fields.title: Add stakeholders (batch 4 of 4)
fields.description: Let's take an even wider look at the ecosystem. Again, try to name at least three key stakeholders per question. Separate stakeholders with commas, press tab to move to the next question.

fields.title: Frequency and depth of contact
fields.description: Final round! By tapping, Indicate the frequency of interactions and number of creative collaborations with %(organization_name)s.

fields.title: Interaction diagram
fields.description:
Excellent, you should now have most of %(organization_name)s's stakeholders here. Have a look through them and see if this already sparks some ideas for future collaborations.


Moving on

New collaborators can be great because they are similar to %(organization_name)s, or because their resources, ways of working or goals are different, complementary or inspiring. In the next few steps, we'll guide you through indicating the similarity of the stakeholders in your mapping.

fields.title: Indicating similarity (1 of 3)
fields.description:
Values or goals

Let's start by reflecting on which of these stakeholders are similar in terms of have values or goals similar to %(organization_name)s. Just tap the stakeholders that have similar values or goals.

Why are we asking this?

Transformations happen when individual steps and experiments come together and begin creating synergies. Although our gut feeling might often be to go to somebody who is similar and find comfort in immediate understanding, there is also value in seeking out partners that are more different from us. 

Wondering why engaging with people dissimilar to you might be valuable? Click here.

fields.title: Indicating similarity (2 of 3)
fields.description:
Ways of working

Secondly, tap stakeholders with ways of working similar to %(organization_name)s.

fields.title: Indicating similarity (3 of 3)
fields.description:
Resources or skills

Final one, we're almost there! Tap stakeholders whose resources or skills are similar to %(organization_name)s.

fields.title: Interaction diagram
fields.description:
You now have almost completed the stakeholder map of %(organization_name)s. Looking at the mapping, you might already realize some gaps or opportunities.


One last exercise

We have one final exercise for you, before you can use filters and different views to make sense of the mapping. Closeness (interactions and creative collaborations) and similarity (values or goals, ways of working, and skills or resources) are important considerations when selecting a new collaborator. However, other factors might be relevant to you. In the next step, we ask you to add a parameter to differentiate stakeholders with. Continue when you are ready!

fields.title: Define your own parameter
fields.description:
Enter a professional or personal characteristic that is meaningful to %(organization_name)s in terms of choosing a future collaborator. You will be able to filter your stakeholders with this characteristic, to quickly see some potential collaborators.

For example, perhaps you would like to base your decision on 

‘living in the same country’

or 

‘great social media influencers’

or 

‘sustainable practitioners’

fields.title: Define your own parameter
fields.description: Now, select the stakeholders for which '%(custom_similarity_parameter)s' applies.

fields.title: You’re done!
fields.description:
Hurray, you have finished creating %(organization_name)s's stakeholder map!


What’s next?

The guided part of this tool is finished, so now you can play with the map and identify untapped potential.

  • ADD STAKEHOLDERSif some stakeholders are missing.
  • Check the LEGEND to remind yourself of what the symbols and edges mean.
  • Apply the FILTERS and view the DIAGRAMS to review and expand your mapping.
  • DOWNLOAD your map as a JSON file to continue later, or as a PDF if you are finished.
  • And most importantly, navigate to ‘SUGGEST COLLABORATORS’ to explore potential future collaborators.
  • You can also RETURN TO THE QUESTIONS if you want to revisit some.

fields.title: Interaction diagram
fields.description: The sphere diagram visualises relationships with %(organization_name)s's stakeholders. From this overview, expand your mapping and use filters to identify potential collaborators.

fields.title: Similarity diagram
fields.description: This Venn diagram groups stakeholders based on similarities. Identify gaps to better understand your map and keep expanding your network.

fields.title: Collaboration suggestions
fields.description:
Based on the stakeholders you input, these are some suggestions for you to consider.

There is no one right answer when choosing a new collaboration partner. There are benefits of working with similar stakeholders, as well as partners that might complement, inspire, or challenge you. The suggestions are just to start your thinking. Go through them, and reflect on a possible collaboration.

What might be in it for %(organization_name)s, and what for them? 

What might they and %(organization_name)s contribute? And what might they and %(organization_name)s gain? 


Click 'NEW SUGGESTIONS' to randomly get some other stakeholders that fit the criteria, if there are any others. When you are done here, just press 'RETURN'.


Click here to read some inspiration regarding small experiments leading to big shifts.

fields.title: Your privacy
fields.description: We use cookies to ensure the functionality of our tool, and to analyze our traffic. Additionally, we gather anonymous data for research purposes. No identifiable data will ever be shared or published. Read more about how we protect your data.

fields.title: Your privacy
fields.description: We use cookies to ensure the functionality of our tool, and to analyze our traffic. Additionally, we gather anonymous data for research purposes. No identifiable data will ever be shared or published. Read more about how we protect your data.

fields.name: Oil and gas production; oil refining
Transport (including civil aviation; railways; road transport)
customer
fields.question: Who are the key customers?
fields.description: In other words, who receives the products, whose needs are served?

fields.name: supplier
fields.question: Who are the key suppliers?
fields.description: In other words, who are materials or resources received from?

fields.name: collaborator
fields.question: Who are the key collaborators?
fields.description: In other words, who are offerings, operations, or other solutions developed with?

fields.name: supporter
fields.question: Who are key supporters?
fields.description: In other words, who make the work possible or easier?

fields.name: extra
fields.question: Anyone or any organization you’d like to add to your stakeholder map right away?

fields.name: customer-customer
fields.question: Who are the customers’ key customers?
fields.description: In other words, who receive products from the product receivers, whose needs do they serve?

fields.name: supplier-supplier
fields.question: Who are the suppliers’ key suppliers?
fields.description: In other words, who do the resource providers receive (raw) materials or resources from?

fields.name: collaborator-collaborator
fields.question: Who are the collaborators' key collaborators?
fields.description: In other words, who else do the collaborators work with to develop new offerings, operations, or other solutions?

fields.name: supporter-supporter
fields.question: Who are the supporters' key supporters?
fields.description: In other words, who make the supporters' work possible or easier?

fields.name: competitors
fields.question: Who are the key competitors?
fields.description: In other words, who is competing for similar customers or resources?

fields.name: inspirer
fields.question: Who are the key sources of inspiration?
fields.description: In other words, who are inspiring, or informing the work?

fields.name: cause
fields.question: Who are the key 'causes'?
fields.description: In other words, who most deserve support, could really benefit from the product?

fields.name: blocker
fields.question: Who are the key progress blockers?
fields.description: In other words, who have conflicting values, or work against the cause?
